Hi everyone,

I'm faced with a "design problem" and I was hoping that some
=
experienced developer could help me figure out how to sort it out.

I use a=
 lot of small interfaces in my application, each of which has a
very precis=
e purpose. Most of my "concrete" classes implement more
than one of these i=
nterfaces.

Now, I was hoping to find a way to refactor my tests so that ea=
ch
interface has its own abstract TestCase. Then, if multiple inheritance
w=
as allowed in Java, I could simply implement each classes concrete
classe's=
 TestCase by inheriting from all the appropriate "interface
TestCases".

Th=
is would allow me to inherit all the general purpose fixtures and
simply ad=
d some new fixtures targeted for the concrete classe's
specific behavior. I=
n a way, I simply want to enforce the "Liskov
Substitution Principle" as si=
mply as possible...

I know multiple inheritance isn't allowed in Java and =
should be
avoided anyway but I'd like to find a simple way to keep the gene=
ral
idea of "interface specific super TestCases" and apply it to classes
im=
plementing several of these interfaces.

Is the general idea a good one ? I=
f it is, what is  the best way to achieve it ?

Thanks in advance,

D.
